text: - [Presenter] Hello everyone.
In this video I'll be discussing

AWS Private Certificate
Authority and the Connector

For Simple Certificate
Enrollment Protocol, or SCEP.
I'll first give you an overview

of AWS Private Certificate
Authority, or AWS Private CA,
followed by discussing Connector for SCEP
and its ability to integrate

with popular mobile
device management systems

such as Microsoft Intune,
accompanied by a demonstration.
All right, now let's get started.

AWS Private CA is a highly
available versatile CA

that helps organizations
secure their applications
and devices using private certificates.

You can create your own
Root CAs or Subordinate CAs
using AWS Private CA.
This allows you to have full control

over your Public Key
Infrastructure, or PKI,

without having to manage the
underlying CA infrastructure.

Using your CAs creator
with AWS Private CA,

you can issue private
X.509 certificates for TLS,

code signing, machine
authentication, and more.
Private Certificates can be used

to secure internal
applications and services

with encrypted communication,
authenticate users,

devices, and APIs within
your organization,

and to cryptographically sign
code and software artifacts.
So what are Connectors?

Connectors would allow you
to replace existing CAs

with AWS Private CA for
environments with an established
native certificate distribution solution.

By using connectors you
can use AWS Private CA
as a single CA solution for a variety
of enterprise use cases,
including mobile devices, Kubernetes,

and Active Directory
Certificate Services, or ADCS.

Connectors for SCEP allow
you to use AWS Private CA

with SCEP compatible applications,
clients, and endpoints.

Typically this means mobile
device management solutions.

Now this brings us to AWS
Private CA connector for SCEP.
As we mentioned earlier,

SCEP is the simple certificate
enrollment protocol,
which is a widely adopted protocol
for getting digital identity certificates
from a certificate authority

and distributing them to mobile
devices and networking gear.
You can use AWS Private CA to enroll

your mobile devices and
networking gear and it works

with popular mobile device
management solutions.
These MDM solutions allow administrators

to control and enforce policies
on these connected devices.

These MDM solutions also
ensure these devices
are in a more secure state
before accessing corporate resources.

Lastly, MDM solutions
allow for the separation
of personal and work data on a device
for bringing your own device.

There are two types of
connectors for SCEP.
The first is a general purpose connector

that is designed to work with
endpoints that support SCEP.
The other type is a connector
designed to work with Microsoft Intune,

which is a cloud-based
endpoint management solution.
This video will discuss
the AWS Private CA connector for SCEP
integrated with Microsoft Intune.
One thing to note:
Using the connector for SCEP

does not require you
to use an MDM solution,
but it is a very popular use case.
All right, with that being said,
let's jump into a demonstration
of using AWS Private CA Connector for SCEP
with Microsoft Intune.

The first step in creating
a connector for SCEP
is to create a private CA.
I went ahead and pre-created a CA
for the purposes of this video.
If you are unfamiliar

with the AWS Private
CA service or console,

please refer to the AWS Private
CA video titled "ACMPCA:

Creating a new private
certificate authority."

The link will be in the
description of this video below.

In case you wanna follow
along with this demo,

I created a Root CA for
demonstration purposes
with the general purpose mode.

This is required for creating
a connector for SCEP.
I left most of the subject options blank

except for the common
name, which I call DemoCA.
I selected RSA 2048 as my key algorithm,

although any option will work
with Connectors For SCEP.
For revocation options,
I did not select either CRL or OCSP
as I will proceed without revocation
for the purposes of this demo.

Just note that Certificate
Revocation Lists
and OCSP are both options

for checking the revocation
status of certificates.

I went ahead and installed
the CA certificate
from the actions dropdown in the console,
making my CA in the Active state.
I can now issue certificates from the CA.

I also went ahead and
exported the CA certificate
to a file called Certificate.pen.

You will want to do this as
well as we will need it later

when we are setting up
our connector for SCEP.

All right, now let's go
straight into setting up

a connector for SCEP
with Microsoft Intune.
Now let's create a connector for SCEP.

I will start by clicking
the Create Connector button

and now we're presented with
some options for our connector.

Now I'll go ahead and
give my connector a name
such as DemoConnector.

Now here we have two
different connector types
as we mentioned earlier.

The general purpose
connector type is designed

to work with endpoints and
applications that support SCEP.

This will work for many
different types of MDMs.
If you're using Microsoft Intune,

you'll use the Microsoft
Intune type connector
of the Private CA Connector for SCEP.
For this video, I will demonstrate

setting up a Microsoft
Intune type connector.

So I will go ahead and
select Microsoft Intune.

Now at this point we'll have
to go into the Azure portal

and perform a few steps to
allow the Connector For SCEP
to be able to access Microsoft Intune.

So in the Azure portal, I
searched for app registrations,
which brought me here to this page.

Under App Registrations, I
will click New Registration.
I will enter in the name field TestApp

and I'll leave all
other fields as default.

Now we have created an
application within Azure.

If we go back to the Private
CA Connector For SCEP console,
we will see that in order to create
our Microsoft Intune type connector,

we need an application
ID and a directory ID.
So I will go ahead and copy those values

from the application we
just created in Azure.
So I'll go copy those fields
and paste them here.
Now I will select my Private CA
that I created in the previous step.
So I'll scroll down,
select my Private CA,
and then click Create Connector.

So now behind the scenes
the CA is being shared
with the Connector For SCEP service
and an endpoint is being created.

One difference with the
Microsoft Intune type connector
versus general purpose connectors

is the challenge password is
managed in Microsoft Intune.
A challenge password is a shared secret

that needs to be distributed
out to your clients and MDMs
to authenticate a request
before issuing a certificate from your CA.
Whereas with general purpose connectors,

the console will create a
challenge password for you
as a managed service.
This happens on your behalf and allows you

to give proper identity
and access management

to control who has access
to these passwords.

You can also rotate
them within the console
or via the API or CLI.

So now that we've created a
Microsoft Intune type connector,
we can move to the next step,
which is setting up access in Azure.
So let's go back to the Azure portal.

Under the app registration
that I just created

called TestApp, I'll click
on Certificates & Secrets
on the left hand side
and then click on Federated Credentials.

Then I'll go ahead and click
the Add Credential button

and from the dropdown I
will select Other Issuer.
So now we will go back

to the Private CA
Connections For SCEP Console

and we're gonna copy and
paste the fields over
for Issuer, Subject, and Audience.
So I'll go ahead and copy those over.

And then here for the credential
name, I will call it Test.
And then I'll click Add.
And so now my Connector For SCEP
has access to Microsoft Intune.

Now we're going to
configure the permissions
the Connector For SCEP has
on my Microsoft Intune configuration.

So here I'll click on API
Permissions on the left hand side.

Then we'll go ahead and
click Add Permissions.
These are the permissions
that the Connector For SCEP will use.

On the screen that pops
up, you can click Intune

and now we can click
Application Permissions
and in the search bar search for SCEP.

We'll click the checkbox
and click Add Permissions.
Now we will add another permission,
this time for Microsoft Graph.
So click Microsoft Graph,

and again, we'll click
Application Permissions.

Then we'll scroll down
and look for Applications.
We'll select Application_Read_All
and Add Permissions.
And now we will click
the Grant Admin Consent for Amazon button.

So now we have set up
our Connector For SCEP
to have access to Intune.

The next step is to set
up a configuration profile

that Intune can use to
push SCEP certificates

and SCEP-trusted user
profiles to my devices.
So now I'll head over to Microsoft Intune.
You'll see here

I'm in the Microsoft
Intune Admin Center portal.
On the left hand side we'll click Devices
and then we'll click Configuration.
So now we can click on the Create button
and then we will add a new policy.
And here we're actually going to create
two configuration profiles.
For the first configuration profile,

I will select my device
that I'll be using,
which is a Windows device for Platform.

And then for Profile Type, I'll
select Trusted Certificate.
So this means we're going to use

our Root CA's CA certificate
that we created earlier
as the trusted certificate that ends up
on our device's trust store.
I'll go ahead, click Create
and name this TrustedCertificate.
Click Next.
And now we need to upload the certificate.

So if you remember, I exported
the certificate earlier
and now here I will upload it,

but I have to change
the .pen to a .cer file.
So I'll go ahead and do that.

And once I change it,
I will upload it here.
Then we can click Next.
And now we can click Add All Devices.

That will add all devices
that are Windows machines

that enroll to my Intune
to have the certificate
added to its trust store.
So we'll click Next and then Create.
And then we can click refresh
to see the policy that we just created.
And there it is.

So now the second configuration
profile that we'll create,
we'll create using the same steps

that we used to create our
first configuration profile,

except this time we'll
select SCEP Certificate
as the Profile Type.

So I select Windows and
then SCEP Certificate.

And this will cause Intune to
push a configuration profile
to your device and then your device

will go and make a request
to the Connector For SCEP
to actually issue a certificate.
So we'll name this SCEP Certificate,
and then we'll click Next.

And for the Certificate
Type, we'll select Device.

And for Subject Name Format,
we will name it Testing
and just be sure to put it in the format
that I entered here.

For Alternative Name, I will
leave this as the default.

You can configure the Validity
Period of your certificate,
which I will also leave as the default.
And then for Key Storage Provider,
we'll go ahead and we'll select

Enroll To Trusted Platform
Module, KSP If Present,
otherwise Software KSP.
For Key Usage, we can select

both Digital Signature
and Key Encipherment.
Then we can scroll down.
For Key Size, we'll select 2048.

And for the Hash Algorithm
we'll select SHA-2.
Now we'll click on the Root Certificate
and we'll select our trusted certificate,

which is our CA
Certificate and click Okay.
For Extended Key Usage I will go ahead

and choose Any Purpose
under Predefined Values.
Then we have the Renewal Threshold,

which means that your
certificates will be renewed
when 20% of its lifetime remains,
which we'll leave as the default.

And now we have to enter
our SCEP server URL,
which is the Connector For SCEP URL.
So we'll switch back

to the Private CA
Connector For SCEP console

and copy the public SCEP
URL and paste it here.
Then we'll click Next.
And again, we have to add all devices.
Click Next and then Create.
Now we'll refresh again

and we'll see our second
configuration profile.
Great.
Now that we have everything set up,

let's see how we can enroll
our device in Microsoft Intune
and see those certificates pushed to it.

To do this, you'll need to
download the Company Portal app.
I went ahead and did this already

and signed in using my
Microsoft Intune credentials,
which is just my username and password.
Now in this wizard,

I will enroll my Windows
machine to Microsoft Intune.
So I'll click this initial link to set up,
then I'll click Next,
and then I'll click Connect.

On the screen that pops
up you'll click Next.
So now it's connecting to my organization.
And this may take a minute to connect
and enroll the device to Microsoft Intune.
So let's just give it a minute
and now we can click Got It.

Now it's just finishing up
connecting to Microsoft Intune.
Great. So now we can click Next.
We'll click Done.

And you'll see your
device that is enrolled
like I have here.

So once you can see your
device that's enrolled,

I will go over to Settings in
the bottom left hand corner,
and then I will click Sync,

which will pull the two
configuration profiles
that we just created.
So this might take a second.

All right, it says the
sync was successful.

So now if I look in my
trust store on this machine,
I should see my CA certificate.

So for Windows, I will
search Computer Certificates,
click Yes,

and then I'll go to
Trusted Root Certification
and then scroll down and find my DemoCA
that I had uploaded to Microsoft Intune
and has now been pulled onto this machine.

So now I created a Windows
machine and rolled it to Intune

and now my CA certificate
that I had issued
with AWS Private CA is now on this machine

and every Windows machine
that gets enrolled from now
on will have the same behavior.

Also, if I go to Personal
and Certificates,
I'll be able to see the SCEP certificate
that was issued as well, which it was.

So what happened here is
I set up the certificate

with a configuration
profile in Microsoft Intune

and when my Windows
machine enrolled to Intune,

it automatically knew to go
ask the Connector For SCEP
for a new certificate.

So it hit the endpoint that
Connector For SCEP had set up

and a certificate was
issued by AWS Private CA.
And that concludes this demonstration.

This shows how easy it
is to use and set up

your AWS Private CA with
a Connector For SCEP
that can be used to enroll

your machines and devices
with Microsoft Intune.

One thing to note though is
if you're trying to enroll
MacOS devices to Microsoft Intune,

the process is very similar
with one key difference.

Setting up the Connector For
SCEP is exactly the same,

and so is creating the
app registration in Azure.

When you create your device
configuration profiles in Intune
you'll select Mac OS as your platform

and then follow the
steps that we performed
in this demo for Windows devices,

some of the options
are slightly different,

but you could still accomplish
what we just did in this demo
with the options presented.
However, before you enroll your device
through Company Portal,

you'll have to perform
one additional step,

which involves going to
Devices, clicking MacOS,

and from there clicking
Enrollment on the left hand side.
Then click Apple MDM Push Certificate,

and this is required to
manage Apple devices.
Then you will download
an Intune certificate signing request,
and then follow the link in step three
to create your MDM Push Certificate.
Will need an Apple ID to obtain one,
and then enter that ID in step four.

And then finally, you can upload
the Apple Push certificate
in this setup wizard in step five.

From there, you can proceed
with enrolling your device

to Microsoft Intune via
the Company Portal app.

In summary, the key takeaways
from this video are that

AWS Private CA is a highly
available, fully managed CA

that removes the
undifferentiated heavy lifting

of managing and operating
on-premises Private CAs.
AWS Private CA supports a wide range

of enterprise PKI use cases
from Kubernetes to IoT devices,

active directory, and mobile
devices via connectors.
AWS Private CA connector for SCEP
allows you to replace existing CAs
for environments with an established
native certificate distribution solution.
And you can use AWS Private CA

to enroll your mobile
devices and networking gear
with the Connector For SCEP.
Thank you for watching this video
on AWS Private CA Connector For SCEP.
If you'd like to learn more
about AWS Private CA Connector For SCEP,

please consult the AWS
Private CA documentation.

For more information on AWS
Private CA specifically,

please check out some of our
other videos on the service
or check out the Private CA workshop.
Thank you and have a great day.
